Author: Leonhard Euler
Description: Leonhard Euler solves the Seven Bridges of Königsberg, founding graph theory—the basis of modern graph theory.

Author: Émile Durkheim & Gabriel Tarde
Description: Durkheim theorizes society as a structure of interdependent institutions; Tarde frames social life as a network of contagious imitation—together laying groundwork for social network theory.

Author: Warren McCulloch & Walter Pitts
Description: McCulloch and Pitts propose the first mathematical model of a neural network, using binary logic to simulate artificial neurons and laying a foundation for artificial neural computation.

Author: Vannevar Bush
Description: Vannevar Bush, in “As We May Think,” describes the Memex, a proto-hypertext system based on associative trails.

Author: Jane Jacobs
Description: Jane Jacobs challenges top-down urban planning in The Death and Life of Great American Cities, framing cities as dynamic, self-organizing networks of interactions rather than rational machines.
Contribution: The Death and Life of Great American Cities

Author: Frank Rosenblatt
Description: Frank Rosenblatt introduces the perceptron, an early algorithm for image classification supervised learning, inspiring decades of research into learning systems.

Author: Marshall McLuhan
Description: Marshall McLuhan publishes Understanding Media, theorizing the "global village" and media as networked extensions of humans.
Contribution: global village, the medium is the message

Author: Ted Nelson
Description: Ted Nelson coins the term “hypertext” and begins Project Xanadu, a nonlinear, reference-rich digital text system

Author: Christopher Alexander
Description: Christopher Alexander introduces “A City is Not a Tree”, critiquing tree-like hierarchies in planning and advocating for semi-lattice (network) structures.
Contribution: A City is Not a Tree

Author: Andries van Dam
Description: Andries Van Dam and Ted Nelson co-develop HES (Hypertext Editing System), the first commercially available hypertext system.
Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), the first packet-switching network and precursor to the internet, goes live.

Author: Elizabeth Fisher
Description: Elizabeth Fisher proposes the "Carrier Bag Theory of Evolution," suggesting that the first human tool was a container for gathering rather than a weapon—reframing survival in terms of care and collectivity.

Author: Bill Hillier
Description: Bill Hillier and researchers at UCL concieve of Space Syntax, using graph theory to model the spatial connectivity and navigability of urban form to explain how built environments influence movement and social interaction.

Author: Neil Postman
Description: Inspired by McLuhan, Neil Postman founded the Program in Media Ecology at New York University

Author: Nicholas Negroponte
Description: Nicholas Negroponte founds the Architecture Machine Group, precursor to the MIT Media Lab.

Author: Tim Berners-Lee
Description: Tim Berners-Lee develops ENQUIRE, an early hypertext system.

Author: Bruno Latour
Description: Bruno Latour and colleagues develop Actor-Network Theory, theorizing society as composed of heterogeneous networks of humans and nonhumans (technologies, texts, objects) that co-produce agency and structure.

Author: Kevin Lynch
Description: Kevin Lynch publishes The Image of the City, a book about how observers take in information of the city, and use it to make mental maps consisting of paths, edges, nodes, districts, and landmarks.

Author: Ursula K. Le Guin
Description: Ursula K. Le Guin publishes "The Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction," arguing for storytelling as a gathering practice focused on everyday life, relationality, and non-heroic narratives—offering an alternative networked epistemology.
Apple releases HyperCard, a stepping stone to user-accessible hypertext systems.
ArcGIS becomes dominant in digital mapping and spatial data modeling, including topology and network analysis.

Author: Tim Berners-Lee
Description: Tim Berners-Lee launched the World Wide Web, composed of HTTP, HTML, and hypertext links.

Author: Michael Benedikt
Description: Benedikt’s book Cyberspace: First Steps explores architecture of digital space as topological, networked, navigable.

Author: Larry Page & Sergey Brin
Description: Larry Page and Sergey Brin develop PageRank, an algorithm that models the web as a directed graph of hyperlinks, revolutionizing search by ranking pages based on their network centrality.

Author: Sadie Plant
Description: In Zeros + Ones, Sadie Plant draws connections between women's histories of weaving, code, and decentralized epistemologies.

Author: Gilles Deleuze & Félix Guattari
Description: Deleuze & Guattari use "rhizome" to describe a post-structialist assemblage that allows connections between any of its constituent elements

Author: Tim Berners-Lee
Description: Tim Berners-Lee propose the Semantic Web (web 3.0) to structure web data as machine-readable graphs by encoding semantics into data using RDF and OWL.

Author: Albert-László Barabási
Description: Barabási publishes Linked: The New Science of Networks, introducing scale-free networks as a model for understanding web graphs, biological systems, and social networks, where few nodes (hubs) hold many connections.

Author: Manuel Castells
Description: Castells’ book Network Society articulates how cities and social life are structured by information flows.

Author: Alexander Galloway & Eugene Thacker
Description: Galloway and Thacker publish The Exploit: A Theory of Networks, theorizing power in decentralized systems.
Contribution: New York School of Media Theory

Description: OpenStreetMap was founded, using a data structure composed of nodes and relations. It grew into a crowd-sourced geospatial dataset with global reach, used in urban planning, humanitarian response, and web cartography.

Author: Joshua Tenenbaum
Description: Joshua Tenenbaum proposes "Theory-Based Bayesian Models" — early steps in semantic graph-based reasoning.

Author: Satoshi Nakamoto
Description: Satoshi Nakamoto releases the Bitcoin whitepaper, proposing a decentralized, peer-to-peer network maintained via a cryptographic ledger known as the blockchain, effectively a graph of transactions and trust.
Google releases Knowledge Graph, a massive entity-relation graph that marked a major shift from keyword matching to semantic understanding.

Author: Tomas Mikolov
Description: Google Brain releases word2vec, a neural embedding model that transformed words into high-dimensional vectors, capturing semantic relationships through cosine distance and enabling graph-like reasoning in textual data.

Author: Shannon Mattern
Description: Shannon Mattern published "Deep Mapping the Media City," a critique of how digital and physical infrastructures are intertwined, highlighting the layered, networked nature of urban media systems.
Facebook releases FAISS, an open-source library for similarity search and clustering of vectors across large embedding spaces.

Launches the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), a peer-to-peer hypermedia protocol that maps and addresses data by its content (hash) instead of location, reshaping file storage as a distributed graph.

OpenAI incorporates dense embedding models and vector search into its retrieval-augmented language model pipelines, improving fine-tuning and enabling semantic memory systems for large-scale language understanding.

Author: Patrick Lewis
Description: Researchers at Facebook AI propose Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), a framework that combines pretrained language models with external document retrieval to generate more informed and accurate responses for knowledge-intensive NLP tasks.
